title: Magnetic and Thermal-sensitive Poly(N-isopropylacrylamide)-based Microgels for Magnetically Triggered Controlled Release
procedures:
1. Synthesis of Surface-modified, Water-dispersible, Magnetic Nanoparticles, Fe3O4 and Fe3O4-NH2
Add 14.02 g of FeCl3, 8.6 g of FeCl2·4H2O and 250 mL water to a 500-mL beaker.
Connect the rotor and controller to set up mechanic stirring. Mix the solution at 300 rpm for 30 min at room temperature (RT).
Add 25 mL of ammonium hydroxide (33%) into the solution at RT and keep stirring (300 rpm) for 30 min. Keep the beaker open.
	CAUTION: Ammonium hydroxide may cause nose irritation if inhaled. This step must be performed inside an appropriate fume hood.
To collect the magnetic iron oxides (Fe3O4), remove the mechanic stirring. Put a magnet under the beaker to collect the black particles.
	
After the Fe3O4 nanoparticles are entirely precipitated, carefully remove the supernatant. Do not shake the beaker while pouring the supernatant to avoid loss of Fe3O4.
Remove the magnet and add 50 mL of fresh water to the beaker.
Shake the beaker to re-disperse the Fe3O4. Repeat steps 1.4 to 1.4.2 three times to purify the Fe3O4.
After the last wash, transfer all the Fe3O4 (10 g) into a 100-mL glass bottle. Add water until the total solution volume is 100 mL. Shake the glass bottle vigorously until no lumps are visible.
	NOTE: The protocol can be paused here. The Fe3O4 nanoparticles are prepared.
Modify the Fe3O4 with aminosilane (Fe3O4-NH2).
	
Take the 100-mL solution from step 1.5 and transfer into a 1,000-mL beaker. Add 10 mL of ammonia solution, 90 mL of water, and 900 mL of ethanol to the beaker.
Use a magnetic stir bar to mix the solution at 300 rpm. Add 500 µL of (3-aminopropyl)triethoxysilane (APTES) dropwise to the beaker at RT and stir for another 12 h.
Purify and collect the Fe3O4-NH2 as described in section 1.4.

Re-disperse 1 g of Fe3O4-NH2 (from step 1.7) in a 20-mL glass bottle with 20 mL water.
	NOTE: The protocol can be paused here. The Fe3O4-NH2 nanoparticles are prepared.
2. Synthesis of Organic-inorganic Hybrid Microgels by Thermo-induced Emulsion
Preparation of Solution 1-1 and 1-2.
	
For solution 1-1, add 0.25 g of PNIPAAm, 5 mL of Fe3O4 solution (from step 1.5), and 0.2 g of PEI to a 50-mL glass bottle. Add 20 mL of water and use a magnetic stir bar to stir at 300 rpm for 30 min.
For solution 1-2, repeat step 2.1.1, but replace Fe3O4 as Fe3O4-NH2 solution (from step 1.8).
To prepare Solution 2, add 0.8 g of PEI and 18.2 mL of water to a 50-mL glass bottle. Use a water bath to heat up the solution to 70 °C for 30 min. Prepare a second bottle of Solution 2.
Preparation of PNIPAAm/Fe3O4.
	
Use an ultrasonic cell disruptor to sonicate (50 w), a magnetic stir bar to stir (300 rpm), and a water bath to heat Solution 2 (70 °C).
Add Solution 1-1 to the heated Solution 2 dropwise using a 3-mL syringe at a rate of 1 mL/min.
Continue sonication, stirring and heating at 70 °C for 30 min.
Cool the solution to RT. Remove the solution from the cell disruptor and water bath.
Collect the microgels by placing the magnet close to the glass bottle.
Remove the supernatant after the microgels have precipitated to the bottom of the glass bottle.
Add another 25 mL of water to the glass bottle and re-disperse the microgels by vortexing. This solution is PNIPAAm/Fe3O4.
		NOTE: The protocol can be paused here.
Preparation of PNIPAAm/Fe3O4-NH2.

Use an ultrasonic cell disruptor to sonicate (50 w), a magnetic stir bar to stir (300 rpm), and a water bath to heat Solution 2 (70 °C).
Add Solution 1-2 to the heated Solution 2 dropwise using a 3-mL syringe at a rate of 1 mL/min.
Continue sonication, stirring and heating at 70 °C for 30 min.
Cool the solution to RT. Remove the solution from the cell disruptor and water bath.
Collect the microgels by placing the magnet close to the glass bottle.
Once the microgels precipitate, remove the supernatant.
Add another 25 mL of water to the glass bottle and re-disperse the microgels by vortexing. This solution is PNIPAAm/Fe3O4-NH2.
		NOTE: The protocol can be paused here.
3. Preparation of Curcumin-loaded Microgels (Cur-PNIPAAm/Fe3O4-NH 2 )
NOTE: These steps must be performed in the dark.
Add 100 mg of Cur and 20 mL of ethanol to a 20-mL of glass bottle.
Take 2 mL of the Cur solution and transfer to the PNIPAAm/Fe3O4-NH2 solution (step 2.4.7). Stir at 400 rpm and RT overnight.
After stirring at 400 rpm and RT overnight, use the magnet to collect PNIPAAm/Fe3O4-NH2 as described in steps 2.4.5 and 2.4.6.
Add another 25 mL of water to the glass bottle and re-disperse the microgels by vortexing. This solution is Cur-PNIPAAm/Fe3O4-NH2.
4. Magnetically Triggered Drug Release
Transfer 10 mL of the Cur-PNIPAAm/Fe3O4-NH2 solution and add 2 mL of water to a 15-mL centrifugation tube.
Place the centrifugation tube in the center of the coil for applying the HFMF20. Apply HFMF at 15 KHz for 20 min.
Withdraw 0.5 mL of the HFMF solution and replace with fresh 0.5 mL of water at every 2 min interval while applying the HFMF.
Transfer the withdrawn solution to the 1-mL cuvette.

Measure the absorption of the withdrawn solution by UV/Vis at 482 nm21.
Determine the concentration of the released drugs by using the relationship of absorption and concentration from a standard calibration curve22.
	NOTE: The standard calibration relation is:
imgsrc://cloudfront.jove.com/files/ftp_upload/55648/55648eq1.jpg
	where the correlation coefficient is 0.9993.
5. Characterization of the Magnetic Microgels
Thermogravimetric analyzer (TGA)23.
	
Measure the weight loss of PNIPAAm/Fe3O4 and PNIPAAm/Fe3O4-NH2 vs. temperature under air atmosphere by TGA.
		
Heat the sample from RT to 100 °C and keep at this temperature for 10 min to eliminate humidity. Heat the sample from 100 °C to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. Weigh the samples.
Plot the weight loss vs. temperature of both PNIPAAm/Fe3O4 and PNIPAAm/Fe3O4-NH2.
			NOTE: The residue weight is either Fe3O4 or Fe3O4-NH2, while the lost weight is PNIPAAm.
FT-IR24.
	
Dry 10 mg of sample with 1 g of KBr at 100 °C overnight.
Press the mixture from step 5.2.1 into pellets as described in the following steps (5.2.2.1 - 5.2.2.5):
		
Grind the materials from step 5.2.1 into a fine powder by using a mortar and pestle.
Place the assembled apparatus (mortar and pestle) into the pellet press. Align the apparatus in the exact middle of the press.
Pump the press until a pressure of 20,000 psi is reached. Let the pellet sit at that pressure for 5 min.
			CAUTION: Align the apparatus in the exact middle of the press otherwise sample will disperse out of the mortar and cause injury from exposure.
Remove the die containing the pellet and the piston from the press.
Turn it upside down and pump the piston to force the pellet out.
Record the FT-IR absorption spectra of samples by FT-IR at frequencies ranging from 400 to 4,000 cm-1 with 4 cm-1 resolution24.
Morphology observations by TEM25.

Drop the sample solution onto a copper-grid coated with a collodion and then dry at RT or in a 70 °C oven overnight.
Take TEM images.
		NOTE: Strong electron beams can damage the samples. Therefore, TEM images should be taken as quickly as possible.
Aqueous-dispersion abilities of polymers and microgels.
	
To prepare PNIPAAm solution, add 7 mg of PNIPAAm and 7 mL of water to a 7-mL glass bottle. Use a vortex to mix the solution until there are no aggregates.
To prepare PNIPAAm/Fe3O4-NH2 solution, transfer 0.7 mL of PNIPAAm/Fe3O4-NH2 solution (step 2.4.7) to a 7-mL glass bottle and add 6.3 mL of water. Use a vortex to mix the solution until there is no precipitation.
To prepare Cur-PNIPAAm/Fe3O4-NH2 solution, transfer 0.7 mL of Cur-PNIPAAm/Fe3O4-NH2 solution (step 3.4) to a 7-mL glass bottle and add 6.3 mL of water. Use a vortex to mix the solution until there is no precipitation.
Take a picture of the solutions (steps 5.4.1 - 5.4.3) using a digital camera.
Place the solutions into an oven and set the temperature to 70 °C. Wait 2 h until equilibrium.
Take another picture of the solutions. To maintain the temperature, take the picture within 1 min. Avoid shaking the glass bottle as this can re-disperse the precipitations.
For magnetic collection of microgels, place the strong magnet close to the Cur-PNIPAAm/Fe3O4-NH2 solution (step 5.4.3). Wait until the microgels are fully collected, then take a picture.
	
Remove the magnet and vortex the microgel solution until fully dispersed. Take another picture.
